citation.article-title: Novel mycolic acid-containing bacteria in the family Segniliparaceae fam. nov., including the genus Segniliparus gen. nov., with descriptions of Segniliparus rotundus sp. nov. and Segniliparus rugosus sp. nov.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Segniliparus gen. nov.

Segniliparus (Seg.ni.li.pa′rus. L. adj. segnis slow; Gr. adj. liparos fat/fatty; N.L. masc. n. Segniliparus the slow fatty one, the one with slow fats, to indicate the possession of slowly reacting fatty acids, i.e. late-eluting mycolic acids detected with HPLC).
Aerobic, brightly staining, acid–alcohol-fast, rod-shaped cells.
No spores or aerial mycelium, non-motile, occasional v-shaped rods but no true branching.
Grows in 3–4 days on LJ, 7H10 and 7H11 at 33 °C.
Colonies are non-pigmented, non-photochromogenic and do not produce a diagnostic odour.
Cell wall contains mycolic acids, tuberculostearic acid and meso-diaminopimelic acid.
Arylsulfatase activity and growth tolerance with sodium chloride are positive in 14 days.
Niacin production is negative.
Semi-quantitative catalase produces >45 mm bubbles.
Cells grow on mycobacterial media and TGY but growth on HI is poor.
Urea is hydrolysed but acetamide, adenine, casein, citrate, aesculin, hypoxanthine, tyrosine and xanthine are not.

d-Glucose, maltose and trehalose are used as carbon sources and produce acid, whereas adonitol, l-arabinose, cellobiose, dulcitol, i-erythritol, galactose, i-myo-inositol, lactose, mannose, melibiose, raffinose, l-rhamnose, salicin and sodium citrate are not.
Utilization of d-fructose, glycerol, d-mannitol, d-sorbitol and sucrose is variable.
Have β-glucosidase and pyrazinamidase activities.
Susceptible to amikacin and sulfamethoxazole.
Strains have the same fatty acid composition, with prominent fatty acids of C10 : 0, C14 : 0, C16 : 0 and tuberculostearic acid.
The GLC thermal cleavage product of the mycolic acids is a C24 : 0 acid-methyl ester.
The HPLC mycolic acid pattern consists of two or three late-emerging groups of peaks with the final peak co-eluting with the high-molecular-mass internal standard.
TLC demonstrates two or three non-polar, high-molecular-mass, non-oxygenated, α+-, α- or α′-mycolic acid chemical functional groups.
Species DNA may or may not amplify with TB11 and TB12 primers for the proposed, selected, actinomycete-specific 65 kDa HSP region.
Species do not produce an R. equi-specific choE virulence factor.
Genomic DNA G+C content is 68·0–72·0 mol%.
The first two described species, Segniliparus rotundus and S. rugosus, are 98·9 % similar by 16S rRNA gene sequence comparison.

16S rRNA gene sequence phylogenetic analysis demonstrates the proposed genus on an extended, distinct tree clade with R. equi as the nearest genetic neighbour, although DNA–DNA hybridization is <2 % with this species.
Environmental habitat is unknown.
The type species of the genus is Segniliparus rotundus.
